author: scott Powers

comments.message: Sounds promising but right now I'm seeing that it can tell dog mitochondria from human mitochondria.  Virus do not have these so the process would have to tell something different.  Perhaps the virus changes the mitochondria enough that the test could tell if it has been compromised.

While differentiating mitochondrial DNA origin was they toy example they used, you could design a similar assay for any oligo targets.  What would be useful is designing a set of probes for the most conserved regions in Ebola that do not align with anything else in the sample.

description: Utilize paper microfluidics (http://www.mf20.org/) to develop a fast and simple detection assay.  Ideally this should be cheap to manufacture in bulk as well as require minimal resources for storage.  Additionally the device must be simple enough to use and read results from those with minimal training to utilize.  The goal would be to rapidly identify cases prior to becoming symptomatic for those at high risk.
summary: Utilize paper microfluidics (http://www.mf20.org/) to develop a fast and simple detection assay.  Prior work has shown the ability to detect sequences using bead bound oligos (http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ac403196b).
title: Fast, easy and cheap assay
